text: have you ever found yourself trapped in
a cycle of unhealthy relationships
feeling like something inside of you is
fundamentally broken do you often
struggle with strong feelings of anxiety
or Detachment towards the people in your
life and wonder why if you've watched
our video on fearful avoidant attachment
and found yourself nodding along you're
not alone many people experience
difficulties in forming and maintaining
healthy relationships due to what's
known as an attachment injury but here's
the good news you're not broken you're
just carrying an attachment injury and
with understanding and effort you can
heal with that said let's dive deeper
into attachment injuries why they happen
and how you can overcome them to form
healthier
connections what is attachment
injury attachment injuries often stem
from relational trauma which can occur
when a char Giver is emotionally
unavailable dismissive or abusive When
We're Young our brains are incredibly
malleable we learn about the world and
our place in it through our
relationships if these relationships are
unhealthy we may develop deep-seated
beliefs that we are Unworthy of Love or
that close connections are dangerous for
example if a parent frequently
criticizes or neglects a child the child
might grow up believing they're
inherently ly flawed or that no one will
ever truly love them these beliefs can
carry over into adulthood making it hard
to form healthy trusting
relationships other common causes of
attachment injuries include emotional
neglect abandonment inconsistent care
poor parental boundaries a chaotic and
unstable home environment like divorce
domestic violence and abuse be it
physical emotional or psychological
such injuries often lead to unhealthy
patterns of fear avoidance or dependency
in our relationships and tend to carry
into adulthood affecting your romantic
relationships friendships and even how
you relate to
yourself signs you have an attachment
injury here are some common ways an
attachment injury May
manifest relationship anxiety constant
worry that your partner will leave or
lose interest in you or that something
will go wrong hyper Independence
refusing help and doing everything on
your own to avoid relying on others
control issues needing to control every
detail in relationships to feel
safe difficulty feeling close to others
struggling to open up and connect
emotionally with people or being overly
needy for closeness wanting to be so
close to someone that it can push them
away like not wanting them to to have
any other friends always wanting to
spend time with them black or white
thinking seeing your partner as either
perfect or terrible with no middle
ground enmeshment losing your sense of
self because you get too wrapped up in
another person emotional instability
having intense and unpredictable
emotional reactions towards
others difficulty with intimacy fear of
being vulnerable or not knowing how to
open up how to heal from attachment
injury healing from an attachment injury
takes time and effort but it's
absolutely possible here are some steps
to help you on your journey step one
recognize your patterns the first step
is to become aware of your attachment
style reflect on your relationships and
notice if you tend to be anxious
avoidant or a mix of
both understanding your patterns is
crucial for making changes
step two understand your past
acknowledge the experiences that
contributed to your attachment injury
this doesn't mean blaming your
caregivers but rather understanding how
your childhood shaped your emotional
responses writing down your thoughts or
talking to a trusted friend can help you
process these
feelings step three cultivate
self-compassion attachment wounds can
hurt us make make us feel down and
negatively impact our self-esteem and
that's why it's so important to
prioritize self-care and self-compassion
when tending to it be kind to yourself
remember your attachment injuries are
not your fault making an intentional
choice to be more forgiving and speak
more kindly towards yourself can do a
lot to ease the emotional burden of
dealing with attachment injuries so
acknowledge and validate your emotions
engage in AC activities that nourish
your body and soul step four choose your
relationships carefully surround
yourself with people who support and
nurture you healthy relationships can
help you experience secure attachment
look for friends and partners who are
consistent trustworthy and willing to
communicate openly step five practice
open honest
communication communication is a key
life life skill and we often learn it
from our family and friends being
assertive means sharing your thoughts
feelings and beliefs clearly and
respectfully it's different from being
passive where you might just agree with
others to avoid conflict or aggressive
where you push your demands onto others
open honest communication will also help
you set healthier boundaries that
protect your emotional well-being it's
not about pushing people away it's about
making a safe space for yourself
this means it's okay to say no when
needed and to clearly Express what you
need in Step six consider trauma focused
therapy sometimes healing from
attachment injury requires the help of a
professional therapists can offer
valuable insights and strategies
tailored to your specific needs therapy
provides a safe space to explore your
emotions and develop healthier
patterns healing from an attack
attachment injury is a journey not a
destination it requires patience
self-awareness and a willingness to grow
remember you are not broken by
recognizing and addressing your
attachment wounds you can break free
from unhealthy patterns and build the
secure loving connections you
deserve so what's one step you're ready
to take today towards healing and
healthier
relationships share your thoughts and
stories in the comments below and if
this video emotionally resonated with
you don't forget to like share with
friends who might need it and subscribe
for more mental Wellness content we also
have videos on hidden signs your past
trauma is still hurting you and what
your attachment style says about your
personality thanks for watching
